reasoning: First and foremost, Netflix sits well outside my circle of competence. I understand consumer staples, insurance, banks and simple industrials with durable moats, but streaming media—with complex content rights, heavy technology spend and unproven long-term economics—is unfamiliar territory. Because I don’t fully grasp the business model or how its economics will hold up over decades, I can’t confidently assess its moat. The streaming space looks fiercely competitive: Disney, Amazon, Apple and deep-pocketed incumbents will slug it out on content budgets. Without clear switching costs or pricing power—customers can easily cancel and jump to another service—I see no sustainable fortress around Netflix’s revenues. Management has shown flair in building a subscriber base, but I lack data on capital allocation: Are they deploying cash wisely or simply chasing growth at any cost? With no reliable balance-sheet or cash-flow figures provided, I can’t judge the financial fortress. Likewise, intrinsic value remains a blank page with no margin of safety to consider. Long term, I’d worry about rising content costs, subscriber churn and the danger of overpaying for infinite new shows. Compared to opportunities I already own—Coca-Cola’s enduring brand, Apple’s ecosystem, Bank of America’s strong deposit base—Netflix doesn’t match up in clarity, moat or valuation. When in doubt, the answer is no. Therefore, I’d pass on NFLX until I truly understand it and can see a durable competitive edge.
